courses.name: Topics in Biological Science - General
courses.description: Selected topics not covered in current offerings. May not be used in partial fulfillment of requirements for a biological science in general education. May be graded on A-F or S/U basis.

courses.name: Topics in Biological Sciences- Biological/Physical/Mathematics
courses.description: Selected topics not in regularly offered courses. Selected sections of this course may be graded either on A-F or S/U basis only.

courses.name: General Principles and Concepts of Biology
courses.description: Emphasizes connections and applications to society and the human condition, science literacy, and critical thinking skills. A discussion of general principles and fundamental concepts of living things. This course is intended for non-science majors.   No more than 5 credits for BIO_SC 1010, BIO_SC 1020, and BIO_SC 1030.

courses.name: General Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory exercises dealing with representative organisms and methods of modern biological sciences.  This course is intended for non-science majors.  No more than 5 credits for BIO_SC 1010, BIO_SC 1020, and BIO_SC 1030.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010 or BIO_SC 1400 or BIO_SC 1010 concurrently

courses.name: General Principles and Concepts of Biology with Laboratory
courses.description: Survey of general principles and basic concepts of life science, emphasizing applications to society and the human condition. Lectures address science literacy and critical thinking and laboratory exercises use representative organisms to complement lecture topics.  This course is intended for non-science majors.  No more than 5 credits for BIO_SC 1010, BIO_SC 1020, and BIO_SC 1030.

courses.name: Basic Environmental Studies
courses.description: Considers the ecosystem, energy and biogeochemical cycles and population dynamics; relation of the environment to agriculture and technology, pollution, power and food production; politico-economic considerations; moral and ethical issues. For non-science majors.

courses.name: Introductory Zoology with Laboratory
courses.description: (same as F_W 1100). Introduces important principles and concepts of zoology. Emphasizes cell biology; evolution; genetics; ecology; structure, function, development of the organism.

courses.name: General Botany with Laboratory
courses.description: Introduction to study of plants. Emphasis on structure, growth, physiology, genetics and reproduction of plants.

courses.name: Evolution for Everyone
courses.description: This course will explore the application of evolutionary theory to modern human affairs.  We will study the processes involved in evolution and investigate evolutionary interpretations of human social behavior (e.g., psychology, mate choice, economics, religion, and morality).   No credit if student has received credit for BIO_SC 2060 or BIO_SC 4600.

courses.name: Introduction to Biological Systems with Laboratory
courses.description: Basic concepts and principles of the structure and function of living systems, from cells to populations. Foundation course for science students intending to complete a 3-semester sequence that also includes genetics and cell biology.

courses.name: Introduction to Biological Systems with Laboratory Honors
courses.description: Basic concepts and principles of the structure and function of living systems, from cells to populations. Foundation course for science students intending to complete a 3-semester sequence that also includes genetics and cell biology.
courses.prerequisites: MATH 1100 and high school chemistry. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Topics in Biological Sciences - General
courses.description: Selected topics not covered in current offerings. May not be used in partial fulfillment of requirements for a biological science in general education. May be graded on A-F or S/U basis.

courses.name: Topics in Biological Sciences- Biological/Physical/Mathematics
courses.description: Selected topics not covered in regularly offered courses. Selected sections of this course may be graded either on A-F or S/U basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Biological Sciences- Biological/Physical/Mathematics - Honors
courses.description: Selected topics not covered in regularly offered courses.   Recommended: a course in biology

courses.name: Undergraduate Seminar in Biological Sciences
courses.description: Discussion and critical evaluation of current topics in biological sciences for intermediate-level students.  Some sections may be graded on either A-F or S/U basis only.

courses.name: Biological Career Explorations
courses.description: Students will learn about career options and choices, construct career portfolios, and interact with current biological professionals. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: How the Brain Works
courses.description: Basic structure and function of the brain; left and right brain studies; gender differences; learning and memory; brain disorders..
courses.prerequisites: C- or above in BIO_SC 1010 or BIO_SC 1500

courses.name: Life of the Cell
courses.description: This course will help students understand basic concepts of biomolecular structure, cell organization, cell membranes, energy and metabolism, cellular communication, and cell division. This course is intended for non-science majors and may not be used to satisfy requirements for either a major or a minor in biological sciences.

courses.name: Community Biology
courses.description: Principles of population biology, ecology, and evolution, including consideration of human impacts on biological communities and ecosystems.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010 or equivalent.  Not open to biology majors

courses.name: Infectious Diseases
courses.description: An introduction to the basic science of bacterial, viral, protozoan, fungal and helminth infections, including discussions of how illness has influenced or been affected by public policy and culture.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1010. Not open to Biology Majors

courses.name: Genetic Diseases
courses.description: This course will discuss the biological basis for genetic diseases, including inherited diseases and non-inherited diseases such as cancer.  The units will include an introduction providing necessary background information, as section studying the technology used to study genetic diseases and several units discussing specific diseases and their impact on history and society.  This course is intended for non-science majors.  Cannot be used to satisfy degree requirements for biology major or biology minor.

courses.name: General Genetics
courses.description: Principles of inheritance in plants and animals; structure and use of genetic material, transmission of genetic information, linkage, modification of genetic information, regulation of genetic activity, population genetics.

courses.name: Introduction to Cell Biology
courses.description: Analysis of cellular organization and function at the molecular level. The mechanisms underlying cellular trafficking, cell motility, and signaling within cells and between cells and their environment will be emphasized.

courses.name: Introduction to Cell Biology- Honors
courses.description: Analysis of cellular organization and function at the molecular level. The mechanisms underlying cellular trafficking, cell motility, and signaling within cells and between cells and their environment will be emphasized.

courses.name: Introduction to Cell Biology - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: Analysis of cellular organization and function at the molecular level. The mechanisms underlying cellular trafficking, cell motility, and signaling within cells and between cells and their environment will be emphasized.

courses.name: Ornithology
courses.description: (same as F_W 2600). Structure, identification, habits, importance of regional birds. Field work, lectures, lab.

courses.name: Ichthyology
courses.description: (same as F_W 2700). A broad introduction to the biology and ecology of fishes. Emphasis will be placed on understanding the adaptations fishes exhibit to aspects of their environment. Includes lab.

courses.name: Internship in Biological Science
courses.description: Work experience in a non-profit, for profit, or governmental organization relevant to the biological sciences.  Intended for students doing internships in which independent research is less than 50% of the experience.  Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.recommendation: junior standing, 12 hours of biological science and 2.70 GPA

courses.name: Directed Independent Research
courses.description: Participation in faculty research activities. May not be used to satisfy degree requirements for BA or BS in biological sciences or the minor in biological sciences.

courses.name: Readings in Biological Science
courses.description: Supervised reading in biological literature. May be repeated up to six hours total credit. Selected sections of this course may be graded either on A-F or S/U basis only.  May not be used in partial fulfillment of Arts and Science foundation requirement.

courses.name: Honors Readings in Biological Literature
courses.description: Selected readings in biological literature for Honors, in consultation with instructor. May not be used in partial fulfillment of Arts and Science foundation requirement.
courses.prerequisites: overall 3.3 GPA;  instructor's consent.  Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Topics in Biological Sciences- Biological/Physical/Mathematics
courses.description: Selected topics not in regularly offered courses. Selected sections of this course may be graded either on A-F or S/U basis only.

courses.name: Topics in Biological Sciences- Biological/Physical/Mathematics - Honors
courses.description: Selected topics not offered in regular curriculum.

courses.name: Topics in Biological Sciences- Biological/Physical/Mathematics - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Selected topics not in regularly offered courses. Selected sections of this course may be graded either on A-F or S/U basis only.

courses.name: Professional Skills
courses.description: This course will focus on application and interview skills for students interested in medical school.  Graded on S/U basis only.
courses.recommendation: junior standing; 3.4 GPA, and biological sciences majors

courses.name: Genetics and Society
courses.description: Introduction to genetics, emphasizing the impact of genetics on human society. Human evolution, molecular genetics, genetic engineering in medicine and agriculture. An intensive writing course.

courses.name: Genetics and Society - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Introduction to genetics, emphasizing the impact of genetics on human society. Human evolution, molecular genetics, genetic engineering in medicine and agriculture. An intensive writing course.

courses.name: The Human Microbiome
courses.description: This course examines the astonishing diversity and medical significance of the microbes that inhabit our bodies.  Interactive discussions explore scientific and ethical dimensions of topics ranging from probiotics and "poop transplants" to the role of microbes in asthma and obesity.

courses.name: The Human Microbiome - Writing Intensive
courses.description: This course examines the astonishing diversity and medical significance of the microbes that inhabit our bodies.  Interactive discussions explore scientific and ethical dimensions of topics ranging from probiotics and "poop transplants" to the role of microbes in asthma and obesity.

courses.name: Plant Systematics
courses.description: Principles of classification of plants; survey of diversity in flowering plant families; identification of local flora; use of keys. Includes lab.

courses.name: Parasitology
courses.description: (same as BIOMED 3250). Parasitism is considered as a fundamental type of interspecies interaction. Principles of parasitism as they apply to animals are presented with emphasis on parasite morphology, biology and host parasite relationships. Includes lab. Recommend: 8 hours of biology.

courses.name: Invertebrate Zoology
courses.description: Structure, ecology and phylogeny of the invertebrate phyla. Includes lab.

courses.name: Invertebrate Zoology - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Structure, ecology and phylogeny of the invertebrate phyla. Includes lab.

courses.name: Herpetology
courses.description: The biology, ecology, taxonomy, and distribution of amphibians and reptiles. Some Saturday field trips.

courses.name: Evolution and Ecology
courses.description: Introduction to principles of evolution and ecology. Topics include natural selection, adaptation, phylogenetic analysis, human evolution, population growth and regulation, population interactions, ecosystem ecology, and human impacts on ecological processes.  No credit for this course if either BIO_SC 3650 or BIO_SC 4600 already completed; may not co-enroll in this course and BIO_SC 4600.

courses.name: Biology of Fungi
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 3510). The diverse roles of fungi in the biosphere will be explored by considering fungi we eat, fungi which destroy our food, fungi in folklore and fungi as global nutrient recyclers. Includes lab.

courses.name: General Ecology
courses.description: Principles of populations, coevolution, density factors, competition; physical environment; concept of community, trophic structure, biotic succession; characterization of biomes, man in ecosystem. Biology majors having completed BIO_SC 3100: 2 hours credit.

courses.name: General Ecology - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Principles of populations, coevolution, density factors, competition; physical environment; concept of community, trophic structure, biotic succession; characterization of biomes, man in ecosystem. Biology majors having completed BIO_SC 3100: 2 hours credit.

courses.name: Tropical Ecology: Methods and Applications
courses.description: Field study of tropical community; additional fee for transportation and accommodations required.

courses.name: Mammalogy
courses.description: (same as F_W 3660). Taxonomy, distribution, structure, habits, importance of mammals; emphasizes those of central United States. Includes lab.

courses.name: Animal Physiology
courses.description: Introduces concepts of vertebrate organ function and homeostatic control emphasizing mammalian physiology. Some comparisons to function in other vertebrates and strategies for coping with environmental stresses introduced. Includes lab.

courses.name: Introductory Entomology
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 3710). Emphasizes the role insects play in the scheme of life.  Topics include insect structure, development, diversity, ecology, communication and behavior, and management.
courses.prerequisites: Completion of 60 credit hours and one of the following: BIO_SC 1100 (or F_W 1100) or BIO_SC 1200, or BIO_SC 1500.

courses.name: Insect Diversity
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 3715). Laboratory exercises emphasizing external insect anatomy, classification, and identification (to family level).  Preparation of an insect collection is required.

courses.name: General Microbiology
courses.description: Principles of microbiology. Includes lab.
courses.recommendation: grades in C range for prerequisites

courses.name: Genetics Laboratory
courses.description: Experimental genetic studies of Drosophila, corn and microorganisms.
courses.prerequisites: C range grade or better in BIO_SC 2200 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Developmental Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory studies of development in sea urchin, chicken and  roundworm.

courses.name: Topics in Biological Science - Biological/Physical/Mathematics
courses.description: Selected topics not in regularly offered courses. May be repeated up to 2 times for credit.

courses.name: Problems in Biological Sciences
courses.description: Individual supervised work to supplement regularly organized courses in biology; introduction to research. Selected sections of this course may be graded either on A-F or S/U basis only.

courses.name: Limnology
courses.description: (same as F_W 4100; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7100, F_W 7100). (lecture/lab: 4 hrs.; lecture only: 3 hrs.) Ecology of inland waters with emphasis on productivity.

courses.name: Analysis of Biological Macromolecules
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7300). Theory/application of techniques used for characterization of proteins, nucleic acids; topics: sedimentation velocity; equilibrium; sucrose density gradients; electrophoresis; spectrophotometry.

courses.name: Physics in Cell and Developmental Biology
courses.description: (same as PHYSCS 4310; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7310, PHYSCS 7310, MPP 7300).  Discusses the role of physical mechanisms in specific cellular and developmental processes and phenomena, in particular those characterizing the embryonic stage of multicellular organisms. Each process and phenomenon is first described in biological terms and then within a physical model, with special emphasis on the interplay between the two descriptions.
courses.prerequisites: PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2760 and BIO_SC 2300, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Molecular Plant Physiology
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 4320; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7320, PLNT_S 7320). Modern physiology of higher plants using common cultivated plants as examples.

courses.name: Introductory Radiation Biology
courses.description: (same as NU_ENG 4328, RADIOL 4328; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7328, NU_ENG 7328, RADIOL 7328). Concepts of ionizing radiations, their actions on matter through effects on simple chemical systems, biological molecules, cell, organisms, man.
courses.prerequisites: junior standing, Sciences/Engineering; one course in Biological Sciences and Physics/Chemistry; or instructor's consent

courses.name: Plant Anatomy
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 4400; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7400, PLNT_S 7400). Comparative structure, growth of meristems; development, structure of important cell types, tissues, tissue systems; comparative anatomy of stem, root, leaf. Emphasizes anatomy of gymnosperms, angiosperms.  Includes lab.

courses.name: Neurobiology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7500). Vertebrate and invertebrate neurobiology, including cell and molecular biology of the neuron, neurophysiology, neuroanatomy, neuroethology and developmental neurobiology.

courses.name: Sensory Physiology and Behavior
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7560). Basic principles of coding and integration of sensory stimuli; neural correlates of animal behavior; environmental influences on postnatal sensory development. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Computational Neuroscience
courses.description: (same as ECE 4580, BIOL_EN 4575;; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7580, ECE 7580, BIOL_EN 7575).  An interdisciplinary course with a strong foundation in quantitative sciences for students in biological and behavioral science and an introduction to experimental methods for students from quantitative sciences.

courses.name: Evolution
courses.description: Surveys various processes in organic evolution and underlying genetic mechanisms.

courses.name: Behavioral Biology
courses.description: (cross-level with BIO_SC 7640). Comparative study of animal ethology. Principles of animal ethology illustrated in different animal phyla.  May be taken with Laboratory for 4 credits.
courses.recommendation: one additional upper-level course in Biological Sciences or Psychology

courses.name: Animal Communication
courses.description: Physical properties of sensory stimuli, receptor mechanisms, functional significance of communication behavior, and multidisciplinary and experimental approaches to current research in animal communication.

courses.name: Plant Population Biology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7660). Covers the ecological and evolutionary processes that influence the distribution and abundance of plant species. Topics include evolution of life history schedules, gender evolution, population growth and demography, competition, herbivory, plant-pollinator interactions, clonal growth, and plant community structure. Includes lab.

courses.name: Avian Ecology
courses.description: (cross-level with BIO_SC 7670). Advanced examination of ecological patterns in birds. Explores the environmental factors affecting the evolution of avian behavior, morphology, community structure and distribution.

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Biology
courses.description: Individually directed field or laboratory research for upperclass students under faculty supervision. Project must be arranged by student and faculty member prior to registration. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.
courses.recommendation: Overall GPA 2.75; 20 hours of Biological Sciences and/or Chemistry

courses.name: Honors Research in Biology
courses.description: Individually directed field or laboratory research for upper-level Honors students, in consultation with a faculty member.  Project must be arranged by student and faculty member prior to registration.  May be repeated for credit. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: overall GPA 3.3; instructor's consent; biology or microbiology major.  Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Undergraduate Research in Biology
courses.description: Individually directed field or laboratory research for upperclass students under faculty supervision. Project must be arranged by student and faculty member prior to registration. May be repeated to a maximum of 6 hours.

courses.name: Honors Research in Biology
courses.description: Continuation of research program.  Successful completion requires public presentation and leads to degree with Honors in biological sciences.  May be repeated for credit for maximum of 6 hours. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 4950H; overall GPA 3.3; instructor's consent. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Special Readings in Biological Sciences
courses.description: Independent readings and discussions of topics in biology selected in consultation with supervising faculty member. Selected sections of this course may be graded either on A-F or S/U basis only.
courses.prerequisites: senior standing in Biological Sciences and instructor's consent

courses.name: Neurobiology Laboratory
courses.description: Laboratory experience with experimental neurobiology, with emphasis on neural networks, motor systems, and developmental neurobiology.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 3700 or BIO_SC 4500 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Developmental Biology
courses.description: Analysis of the molecular, genetic, cellular, and morphological processes responsible for phenotypic changes in developing organisms. A variety of experimental systems are discussed to identify common mechanisms used by developing organisms.

courses.name: Developmental Biology
courses.description: Analysis of the molecular, genetic, cellular, and morphological processes responsible for phenotypic changes in developing organisms. A variety of experimental systems are discussed to identify common mechanisms used by developing organisms.

courses.name: Molecular Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Emphasizes recently developed genetic and biochemical techniques; illustrates how they apply to contemporary problems in biological research.

courses.name: Molecular Biology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7976). Molecular mechanisms of DNA replication, mutation, recombination and gene expression in prokaryotes, eukaryotes, and their viruses; gene fine structure; genetic engineering.

courses.name: Cancer Biology
courses.description: (same as BIOCHM 4978; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7978, BIOCHM 7978).  The cellular and molecular basis of cancer, with emphasis on the application of genomics, proteomics, and genetic manipulations in model organisms to the study of cancer biology.

courses.name: Cellular Interactions in Health and Disease
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7980). The cell as a functional unit.
courses.prerequisites: 10 hours Biological Sciences and 5 hours Physics and 5 hours Organic Chemistry
courses.recommendation: some background in Biochemistry and/or Molecular Biology

courses.name: Human Inherited Diseases
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7982). Analysis of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying inherited diseases in humans. Topics include genetics of sex determination, metabolic disorders, cancer, blood groups, transplantation, AIDS.

courses.name: Human Inherited Diseases - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7982). Analysis of the molecular and cellular mechanisms underlying inherited diseases in humans. Topics include genetics of sex determination, metabolic disorders, cancer, blood groups, transplantation, AIDS.

courses.name: Molecular Ecology
courses.description: Application of molecular genetic techniques to topics in ecology and population biology such as sex ratios, dispersal, mating systems, biogeography and conservation genetics.

courses.name: Mammalian Reproductive Biology
courses.description: Adult reproductive anatomy, physiology and behavior; gametogenesis and fertilization; placentation; sexual differentiation; parturition; maternal behavior and lactation; puberty; reproductive aging; reproductive ecology.

courses.name: Neurology of Motor Systems
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 7986). Examination of the function of neural networks at all levels, from properties of single neurons to large collections of neural elements.

courses.name: Nerve Cells and Behavior
courses.description: The cellular basis of behavior. Molecular and cellular properties of nerve cells, as related to behavior, will be represented and discussed.

courses.name: Vertebrate Histology and Microscopic Anatomy
courses.description: Microscopic anatomy of vertebrate tissues and organs. Includes lab.

courses.name: Senior Seminar
courses.description: Readings and critical evaluation of selected problems and theories in biology. Offered in one or more sections, with specialized subdisciplinary emphasis.

courses.name: Senior Seminar - Honors
courses.description: Readings and critical evaluation of selected problems and theories in biology. Offered in one or more sections, with specialized sub disciplinary emphasis.
courses.prerequisites: Biological Sciences major, senior standing; Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Senior Seminar - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: Readings and critical evaluation of selected problems and theories in biology. Offered in one or more sections, with specialized sub disciplinary emphasis.
courses.prerequisites: Biological Sciences major, senior standing; Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Senior Seminar - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Readings and critical evaluation of selected problems and theories in biology. Offered in one or more sections, with specialized subdisciplinary emphasis.

courses.name: Topics in Biological Sciences
courses.description: Advanced topics not in regularly offered courses. May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Limnology
courses.description: (same as F_W 7100; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4100, F_W 4100). (lecture/lab: 4 hrs.; lecture only: 3 hrs.) Ecology of inland waters with emphasis on productivity.

courses.name: Analysis of Biological Macromolecules
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4300)Theory/application of techniques used for characterization of proteins and nucleic acids.  Topics include sedimentation velocity; equilibrium; sucrose density gradients; electrophoresis; spectrophotometry.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 2300; BIOCHM 4270; MATH 1500; 1 year of physics

courses.name: Physics in Cell and Developmental Biology
courses.description: (same as PHYSCS 7310 and MPP 7300; cross-level with BIO_SC 4310, PHYSCS 4310).  Discusses the role of physical mechanisms in specific cellular and developmental processes and phenomena, in particular those characterizing the embryonic stage of multicellular organisms. Each process and phenomenon is first described in biological terms and then within a physical model, with special emphasis on the interplay between the two descriptions.
courses.prerequisites: instructor's consent or PHYSCS 1220 or PHYSCS 2760 and BIO_SC 2300

courses.name: Molecular Plant Physiology
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 7320; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4320, PLNT_S 4320). Modern physiology of higher plants using common cultivated plants as examples. May be taken with or without laboratory.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1200 or BIO_SC 1500 and 5 hours Chemistry

courses.name: Introductory Radiation Biology
courses.description: (same as NU_ENG 7328, RADIOL 7328, V_M_S 7328; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4328, NU_ENG 4328, RADIOL 4328). Concepts of ionizing radiations, their actions on matter through effects on simple chemical systems, biological molecules, cell, organisms, man.
courses.prerequisites: Sciences/Engineering; one course in Biological Sciences and Physics/Chemistry; or instructor's consent

courses.name: Summer Institute in Biotechnology
courses.description: Development of experiments in molecular genetics for use in high school biology laboratories. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Molecular Biology Laboratory
courses.description: Emphasizes recently developed genetic and biochemical techniques; illustrates how they apply to contemporary problems in biological research.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 2200, BIOCHM 4272 or concurrent registration in BIO_SC 4976

courses.name: Plant Anatomy
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 7400; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4400, PLNT_S 4400).  Comparative structure, growth of meristems; development, structure of important cell types, tissues systems; comparative anatomy of stem root, leaf.  Emphasizes anatomy of gymnosperms, angiosperms.  Includes lab.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Vertebrate Histology and Microscopic Anatomy
courses.description: Microscopic anatomy of vertebrate tissues and organs. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Neurobiology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4500). Vertebrate and invertebrate neurobiology, including cell and molecular biology of the neuron, neurophysiology, neuranatomy, neurothology and developmental biology.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Sensory Physiology and Behavior
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4560). Basic principles of coding and integration of sensory stimuli; neural correlates of animal behavior; environmental influences on postnatal sensory development.

courses.name: Computational Neuroscience
courses.description: (Same as BIOL_EN 7575, ECE 7580; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4580, BIOL_EN 4575, ECE 4580). An interdisciplinary course with a strong foundation in quantitative sciences for students in biological and behavioral sciences and an introduction to experimental methods for students from quantitative sciences.

courses.name: Behavioral Biology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4640). Comparative study of animal ethology. Principles of animal ethology illustrated in different animal phyla.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 1500 and one additional upper-level course in Biological Sciences or Psychology

courses.name: Plant Population Biology
courses.description: (cross-leveled wit BIO_SC 4660). Covers the ecological and evolutionary processes that influence the distribution and abundance of plant species. Topics include evolution of life history schedules, gender evolution, population growth and demography, competition, herbivory, plant-pollinator interactions, clonal growth, and plant community structure.

courses.name: Avian Ecology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4670). Advanced examination of ecological patterns in birds. Explores the environmental factors affecting the evolution of avian behavior, morphology, community structure and distribution.

courses.name: Molecular Biology
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4976). Molecular mechanisms of DNA replication, mutation, recombination and gene expression in prokaryotes, eukaryotes, and their viruses; gene fine structure; genetic engineering.

courses.name: Cancer Biology
courses.description: (same as BIOCHM 7978; cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4978, BIOCHM 4978). The course will cover major molecular and cellular aspects of cancer. Students will read original research articles, present overviews and lead class discussions.
courses.prerequisites: BIOCHM 4270, BIO_SC 2300 and BIO_SC 4976 or equivalent

courses.name: Cellular Interactions in Health and Disease
courses.description: (cross-leveled with BIO_SC 4980). Advanced discussion of topics in cell biology and genetics as they relate to health and disease. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Human Inherited Diseases
courses.description: Advanced analysis of the molecular basis for genetic disorders in humans.  Topics will include both Mendelian and complex traits with readings from the primary literature. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Neurology of Motor Systems
courses.description: (cross-leveled witgh BIO_SC 4986). Examination of the function of neural networks at all levels, from properties of single neurons to large collections of neural elements.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Non-thesis Research
courses.description: Independent research not leading to a thesis. Some sections may be offered on either A-F or S/U grading basis.

courses.name: Topics in Biological Sciences- Biological/Physical/Mathematics
courses.description: Advanced topics not in regularly offered courses.

courses.name: Professional Survival Skills
courses.description: Introduction to resources, facilities, and communication skills for professional careers in biological sciences. Topics include computer resources, accessing scientific literature, making slides and figures, grantsmanship, resume preparation, manuscript review, and research presentation.

courses.name: Ethical Conduct of Research
courses.description: (same as BIOCHM 8060). Discussion of ethical issues in biological research, including the rules and conventions for appropriate research conduct. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Professional Communication Development
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to develop professional communication skills in students that are planning to attend (or are in their first year of) graduate training. Some sections may be offered with A-F or S/U grading option.

courses.name: Workshop in Area of Specialization
courses.description: Intensive course in the theory and methodology of biological investigation. Conducted by visiting scientists. Offered in one or more specialized sections. May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Problems in Biological Sciences
courses.description: Research not expected to terminate in thesis, or individual advanced study in special subjects.

courses.name: Seminar
courses.description: Current topics in the biological sciences. Open to all graduate students. Graded S/U basis only.

courses.name: Research in Biological Sciences
courses.description: Research leading to thesis. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Seminar in Areas of Specialization
courses.description: Offered each semester in one or more specialized sections followed by the topic title of the seminar. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Plant Genetics
courses.description: Genetic approaches to molecular and biochemical studies in maize, wheat, and Arabidopsis.
courses.prerequisites: General Genetics and course in Cell Biology or Plant Physiology

courses.name: Fungal Genetics and Biology
courses.description: Introduction to fungal research, with an emphasis on genetics, biochemistry, cell and molecular biology, and pathogenicity of fungi. Graded A-F only.

courses.name: Developmental Genetics
courses.description: An overview of various developing systems amenable to classical and molecular genetic analysis.  Specific developmental phenomena will be introduced in particular model systems, with an emphasis on experimental approaches used to address the underlying mechanisms.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 2200 and BIOCHM 7270, BIOCHM 7272, or equivalent

courses.name: Stem Cell Biology
courses.description: A comparative approach to stem cell biology, with emphasis on embryonic, neural and bone marrow-derived stem cells in rodents and humans.  Ethical considerations associated with the use of stem cells to study development and repair mechanisms will also be addressed. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Microscopy Techniques
courses.description: Electron microscopy and modern light microscopy techniques including epiflourescence, confocal flourescence microscopy, low light video microscopy, differential interference optics, and computerized image analysis.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 4990 or BIO_SC 8350 and instructor's consent

courses.name: Advanced Cell Biology
courses.description: Structure and function of membranes; cell ultrastructure; organellar function; cellular movement; microtubules; microfilaments; mitosis and meiosis.

courses.name: Introduction to Plant Metabolism
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 8362, BIOCHM 8362). This course is part of a series that aims to provide a solid conceptual foundation in interdisciplinary plant biology for graduate students with a research emphasis in plant biology.  This course examines the basic concepts and techniques used to understand plant metabolism.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Molecular Cell Biology
courses.description: (same as BIOCHM 8365, PLNT_S 8365). This course is part of a series that aims to provide a solid conceptual foundation in interdisciplinary plant biology for graduate students with a research emphasis on plant biology.  This course examines the basic concepts and techniques used to understand molecular cell biology.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Plant Developmental Biology
courses.description: Critical discussions of recent publications in plant development, with particular focus on developmental genetics.

courses.name: Integrative Neuroscience I
courses.description: (same as NEUROSCI 8440).  Organization, development and function of the nervous system focusing on cellular and molecular processes.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Integrative Neuroscience II
courses.description: (same as NEUROSCI 8442).  Organization and function of the nervous system at the systems level to examine processes of behavior and cognition.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Developmental Neurobiology
courses.description: Principles of neural development. Development of neuron and nerve patterns, axon growth, synapses, and development of behavior.

courses.name: Advanced Cancer Biology
courses.description: A study of the molecular basis of cancer, including topics in tumor cell biology, interactions between cancer cells and normal cells, mechanisms of metastasis, and novel approaches to development of new chemotherapies.

courses.name: Introduction to Plant Stress Biology
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 8505). This course is part of a series that aims to provide a solid conceptual foundation to interdisciplinary plant biology for graduate students with a research emphasis in plant biology.  This course examines the basic concepts and techniques used to understand plant stress biology.  Graded on A-F basis only

courses.name: Sensory Ecology
courses.description: A study of information exchange and acquisition in organisms, with an emphasis on communication, orientation, and predator detection.  The course will also examine the effects of biotic and abiotic factors on sensory systems.

courses.name: Design of Ecological Experiments
courses.description: Principles of experimental design in the context of ecological, behavioral, and evolutionary research.

courses.name: Current Concepts in Conservation Biology
courses.description: Survey of current concepts in conservation biology literature.  Discussions will provide students with an appreciation of the historical development of concepts, the interdisciplinary nature of conservation problems, and the research required for effective solutions.

courses.name: Phylogenetic Methods and Applications
courses.description: A review of principles for constructing and testing phylogenies followed by a survey of methods for inferring ancestral characteristics and adaptive features in living species.

courses.name: Molecular and Network Evolution
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 8633). Evolution of biological macromolecules and networks, including sequence analysis algorithms and theory, phylogenetics, gene duplication, genome evolution, principles of biological networks. Development of computational skills emphasized.

courses.name: Ecological and Evolutionary Genomics
courses.description: (same as PLNT_S 8650).  This course is designed to give a background in evolution and then explore an exciting new field:  Ecological and evolutionary genomics.  We will study genes that affect fitness and how whole genomes evolve.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Ecological Genetics
courses.description: Population genetics and evolutionary theory, with emphasis on studies of natural populations.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 2200, BIO_SC 3100 or BIO_SC 3650, and STAT 1400 or equivalent

courses.name: Speciation
courses.description: Advanced discussion of species concepts and the processes of formation of species.

courses.name: College Science Teaching
courses.description: (same as LTC 8724, PHYSCS 8310, ASTRON 8310). Study of learner characteristics, teaching strategies, and research findings related to teaching science at the post-secondary level.

courses.name: Science Outreach: Public Understanding of Science
courses.description: (same as AN_SCI 8725, PHYSCS 8350, LTC 8725). Development of presentations to adult audiences on the science underlying issues of current interest.  May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Integrating Science with Outreach
courses.description: (same as LTC 8726). This course provides an opportunity for students to earn credit for outreach activities in the community.  Students will capitalize on their area of study and scientific expertise in developing, implementing, and evaluating related outreach activities.  May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Advanced Community Ecology
courses.description: Detailed examination of new happenings in population and community ecology. Topics vary but will include species interactions, community structure, reproductive strategies.

courses.name: Plant/Animal Interactions
courses.description: Discussion and lectures on herbivory, pollination biology, and dynamics of fruit and seed dispersal from ecological and evolutionary perspectives.

courses.name: Advances in Human Genetic Disorders
courses.description: Critical review of recent publications describing the molecular and cellular processes underlying genetic disorders in humans.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: BIO_SC 4982 or concurrent enrollment in BIO_SC 7982

courses.name: Research in Biological Sciences
courses.description: Research leading to dissertation.Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Molecular Biology II
courses.description: (same as MICROB 9432, BIOCHM 9432) Detailed experimental analysis of eukaryotic cellular and molecular biology relevant to cellular and viral gene expression, post-transcriptional and post-translational modifications and genome replication. Models for developmental genetic analysis and genetic determinants controlling processes utilizing the current literature will be examined.

courses.name: Molecular Biology of Plant Growth and Development
courses.description: (same as BIOCHM 9468). Molecular biology of plant hormones, signal transduction, environmental signals.
